node.title: America restores it’s dignity
node.content:
I really can’t overstate how meaningful the results of this 2020 election were for me, and I know that I’m not alone here. The Trump Presidency was appalling; the world watched in slack-jawed awe four years ago as the most crass, arrogant, and ignorant person conceivable was elected president. From the outside it must have looked like the behavior of a self-destructive narcissist; from the inside it felt like a betrayal and a gut punch. Electing him once was a hair-brained misstep, electing him a second time would have been an unforgivably deliberate act of willful malice. And for a second there, whoooo boy I really thought we were going to elect him a second time. For a second, I really got scared that my country was not just broken, but beyond fixing.

For as long as I’ve lived, I’ve believed that America was broken but very much worth fixing. And I wasn’t ready to lose that. I wasn’t ready to lose all faith in my beautiful, fucked up country. And thank God I didn’t have to, because my beautiful, fucked up country came through and did the right thing. We did the right thing.

That’s all I have to say for now. It’s been a few days but I still cry when I think about it. Tears of deep, deep gratitude.

node.title: RIP James Carse
node.content: He was an author, philosopher, NYU Professor, and general gangster who had the voice of a 40 year old man despite being 90. He wrote a book called Finite and Infinite Game which will blow my mind, once I finally finish it and give it the focus it deserves. I’ll write a review of it sometime later and try to do it justice, for I have no hope of doing it justice here and now. This post is just to say that JC was a brilliant and deeply original thinker (and maybe also to test the post-rendering order on my site.) Anyway, rest in peace beautiful man.

node.title: I just lost my job.
node.content:
Yep! It happened yesterday in the early afternoon. I got a call from my boss who told me in a very honest and professional tone that he and his partner were having issues, that the business was going to need restructuring, and that he couldn’t justify keeping me on the payroll while there were fundamental questions about if and how the business would move forward. I told him I understand completely.

Tyler, if you’re reading this, it’s been a real pleasure working with you dude. You made me the third team member of your business, which was and continues to be your baby; you made room for me when funding was slim and you didn’t have to. You know this, but I ain’t got nothing but love for Moximetrics. Thanks homie.

Back to the general reader. That’s really it. It was only a part time job, but it was fun and I liked it. Alas I am now back on the job search. Kind of serendipitous that it happened in the middle of this 10-day portfolio challenge I’ve given myself though…

All in all, I’m not tripping; I’m okay and I know I’ll be okay. Just gotta get back to work, whatever that means. Right now it means finishing this motherfucking portfolio page ðŸ™‚

node.title: It’s 11:45 pm on election day and I haven’t looked at the results yet.
node.content:
Well, that’s not entirely true. I checked about two hours ago and was not met with the kind of feedback I was hoping for. To be clear, I’m supporting Joe Biden on this one. And when I checked two hours ago, it was a much closer race than basically every single poll had predicted going into this thing.

I could say I don’t know how anyone supports Trump, but we’ve been past that for a while now. There’s clearly a lot about this nation, and about people in general, that I don’t understand.

Regardless… we’re going to get what we deserve, one way or another.

node.title: More Work, Less Energy
node.content:
Being a hard worker is a good thing. At least, we think it is. And don’t get me wrong, busting one’s ass is sometimes necessary and completely unavoidable if you want to do anything worthwhile, whether it’s building a company, paying your bills, or raising your kids.

But I’ve started to wonder about all the times when hard work was, well, unnecessary. Or at least inefficient. And I’ve started to believe that’s the case a lot more often than we think.

I once wrote an if-else statement that was like 25 lines of code. (this was during my first two months of bootcamp, mind you) and it took forever. All the typing, copy/pasting, and carefully organizing my data ended up delivering me the result I was hoping for (the app worked!) but it was horribly, embarrassingly, inefficient. I could have done the same thing with about 4 line of code instead.

I also love tracking the hours I spend working on coding as a measure of how productive I’m being, or how “hard” I’m working. But if I had written that if-statement the efficient way, those hours I was so proud of logging simply wouldn’t have been logged. Does that mean I would’ve been a less hard worker? Well, yes. But it also means, in that case, I would have been a better coder.

Anyway, my thought for now is, there’s an important caveat to hard work that I think we should talk about more. It’s that it doesn’t mean much if the work is being done inefficiently. Work smart, not hard sums it up nicely. I made that up, by the way.

node.title: Development is Complicated.
node.content:
I’m writing this as a sample blog post for my personal site. It’s gonna be a for-real blog page, too though. So I guess this is a legitimate blog post after all. And here’s what I have to say: progress is slow, but progress is undeniable as long as I’m sitting here, chipping away.

Here’s another interesting thought: I was under the impression that I have to be clear-headed to sit down and code. Turns out I wasn’t today, but as I got deeper and deeper into the work my head cleared itself. Huh. Or I should say the deeper the work, the clearer my head becomes. That would be lovely because it would indicate that the way to find that clear-head isn’t so mysterious, and that a clear-head is not requisite, but rather a consequence, of doing challenging work. Which, so far, for me, this definitely is.
